title: `rails new --skip-test` breaks `rails --tasks`
body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Generate a new rails app with the flag `--skip-test`, or comment out `require "rails/test_unit/railtie"` in an existing app's `application.rb` to disable the test framework.
2. Run `bin/rails --tasks` ~(or `bin/rake --tasks`)~

### Expected behavior
Rails outputs a list of available tasks.

### Actual behavior
Rails outputs `Unrecognized command "default" (Rails::Command::UnrecognizedCommandError)`

### System configuration
**Rails version**: 7.1.2

**Ruby version**: 3.2

### Details
Here's the sequence that leads to the bug as I understand it:
1. Rake is invoked without a valid task name so its `top_level_tasks` [only contains the default task](https://github.com/ruby/rake/blob/a7ad109522d38b39024d6dd6b0def75e0eaedf46/lib/rake/application.rb#L791).
2. In Rails, the [default task is set](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/c66b655bf8948622722c24e6455b9b41febbe3a6/railties/lib/rails/test_unit/testing.rake#L6) in a file loaded by `rails/test_unit/railtie`, which doesn't get loaded if tests are skipped.
3. Rails [raises an UnrecognizedCommandError](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/c66b655bf8948622722c24e6455b9b41febbe3a6/railties/lib/rails/commands/rake/rake_command.rb#L23) before rake has a chance to [print the list of tasks](https://github.com/ruby/rake/blob/a7ad109522d38b39024d6dd6b0def75e0eaedf46/lib/rake/application.rb#L134).

### Workaround
Add the line `task :default` to a .rake file to set an empty default task.
